RAID 0 (striping) provides high data throughput and I/O performance by distributing data across multiple disks. This configuration is suitable for SAP HANA workloads that require high performance and low latency

Selected Answer: D
You don't need to configure any redundancy level using RAID volumes since Azure block storage keeps three images of a VHD.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sap/workloads/hana-vm-operations-storage

Basically, RAID0 is not recommended for any enterprise DB system. The best throughout is RAID5 here. RAID10 is better.

questions.question_text:
You plan to deploy an SAP production landscape that uses SAP HANA databases on Azure.

You need to configure the storage infrastructure to support the SAP HANA deployment. The solution must meet the SAP issued requirements for data throughput and I/O.

How should you configure the storage?

HOTSPOT -
You have an on-premises SAP environment.
Backups are performed by using tape backups. There are 50 TB of backups.
A Windows file server has BMP images of checks used by SAP Finance. There are 9 TB of images.
You need to recommend a method to migrate the images and the tape backups to Azure. The solution must maintain continuous replication of the images.
What should you include in the recommendation? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Azure Databox for Tape Backups and Azure Databox edge for Images as in the question continuous replication is only mentioned for images and not backups.

you can use storage explorer where the azcopy is built in.
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/azcopy-support-in-azure-storage-explorer-now-available-in-public-preview/

comments.content: Do you know whether the speeds of both azcopy command and azcopy in storage explorer are the same? if the speed of azcopy in storage explorer is fast than azcopy command, are the processes of azcopy command and azcopy in storage explorer different?

discussion.content:
That's a duplicated question, and the proper answers are:
Azure DataBox & Azure DataBox
as we have databox option for both option now, these are the answers imho:databox\databox

1. Azure Data Box
2. AzCopy as a Programmatic Transfer tool.
Please refer : https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-choose-data-transfer-solution

1 : Az Databox 
2 : Storage explorer ( Create a fileshare -> Click on connect VM it would allow to map this fileshare on your onprem , and then a continuous replication can be done for images )

AzCopy is wrong because we have "You have an on-premises SAP environment." AzCopy only works inside of Azure Storage accounts, meaning you move data inside of Azurehttps://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-use-azcopy-v10?ranMID=24542&ranEAID=a1LgFw09t88&ranSiteID=a1LgFw09t88-Mem8nvFzGfYWH3H6UZybhw&epi=a1LgFw09t88-Mem8nvFzGfYWH3H6UZybhw&irgwc=1&OCID=AID2000142_aff_7593_1243925&tduid=%28ir__0iqueirz0gkfqmhckk0sohz3wf2xpl2rgtmn1yoo00%29%287593%29%281243925%29%28a1LgFw09t88-Mem8nvFzGfYWH3H6UZybhw%29%28%29&irclickid=_0iqueirz0gkfqmhckk0sohz3wf2xpl2rgtmn1yoo00

So we are left with Azure Databox and Azure Data Box Edge. Difference:
Azure Databox goes over the internet
Azure Data Box Edge is a pyhsical enviroment shipped to the customer

So I will go with Azure Databox due to the "must maintain continuous replication of the images" for images and tape. Copying from tape backup is slow so we have no problem using the internet.
Tape backups => Azure Databox
File server => Azure Databox

comments.content:
this question really tricky also. "it mentioned, maintain continuous replication of images"
For tape backups, it could be Azure Databox. 
For file server (9TB of images), it could be Azure Data Box Edge (continuous replication)
Any thoughts?

discussion.content: Shall we say, Azure Databox and AzCopy are final answers? Any thoughts

Azure Databox for Tape Backup as it is greater than 40 TB. Azure Databox Edge for Images backup as it requires continuous replication. Also, continuous replication is only sought for Image unlike Tape backup.

I will choose Data Box Edge for both scenarios
50 TBs and 9 TBs - we can not prefer azcopy for TBs data <

comments.content: For continuous replication, I agree with you.

discussion.content: The key of this question is continuos replication... only Data Box Edge support this ... look: https://docs.microsoft.com/es-es/azure/storage/common/storage-solution-periodic-data-transfer?toc=/azure/storage/blobs/toc.json
For both the answer should be Azure Databox, as we have a huge volumetry 9Tb and 50Tb, you can't use Azcopy neither Azure Storage explorer to copy TB of data

Databox recommended for data > 40 TB. 
First is correct and second should be AzCopy

Backup - Azure Databox
Files(images) - Azcopy

The solution must maintain continuous replication of the images. -> azcopy
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-ref-azcopy-sync

comments.content: Would you use AzCopy to copy TB? It's crazy ...

questions.answer_description:
Tape backups: Azure DataBox -
The Microsoft Azure Data Box cloud solution lets you send terabytes of data into Azure in a quick, inexpensive, and reliable way. The secure data transfer is accelerated by shipping you a proprietary Data Box storage device. Each storage device has a maximum usable storage capacity of 80 TB and is transported to your datacenter through a regional carrier. The device has a rugged casing to protect and secure data during the transit.
File server: Azure Storage Explorer
Azure Storage Explorer is an application which helps you to easily access the Azure storage account through any device on any platform, be it Windows, MacOS, or Linux. You can easily connect to your subscription and manipulate your tables, blobs, queues, and files.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databox/data-box-overview https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/master/articles/vs-azure-tools-storage-manage-with-storage-explorer.md

choices.B: a zone-redundant frontend IP address for the internal Azure Basic Load Balancer
choices.C: a zone-redundant frontend IP address for the internal Azure Standard Load Balancer
choices.D: a zonal frontend IP address for the internal Azure Standard Load Balancer
choices.A: a zone-redundant public IP address for the internal load balancer

questions.question_text:
You plan to deploy a high availability SAP environment that will use a failover clustering solution.
You have an Azure Resource Manager template that you will use for the deployment. You have the following relevant portion of the template.
//IMG//

What is created by the template?

discussion.content: Answer should be 'D'. The JSON file shows parameter 'Zone=1' which means this JSON will create a Zonal Frontend. If a Zone redundant ILB has to be created then the JSON file will not have parameters related to Zone.

In the context of the load balancer,zone-redundant always means multiple zones and zonal means isolating the service to a single zone.You can choose to have a frontend guaranteed to a single zone, which is known as a zonal frontend. This scenario means any inbound. I think Ans is D.

answer is D . Since a Zone number is specified. 
A Load Balancer can either be zone redundant, zonal, or non-zonal.
Goto azure portal and create a load balancer it would give you 5 options possibly for Availability Zone : No Zone , Zone Redundant , 1 , 2, 3.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/load-balancer/load-balancer-standard-availability-zones
